Accepted Manuscript
Title: NANO-CAGES Phosphides or nitrides for better NLO properties? A detailed comparative study of alkali metal doped nano-cages
Authors: Maria, Javed Khattak, Ralf Ludwig, Khurshid Ayub
PII: S0025-5408(16)32142-0 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/doi:10.1016/j.materresbull.2017.03.065 Reference: MRB 9261
To appear in: MRB
Received date: 28-11-2016 Revised date: 27-2-2017 Accepted date: 30-3-2017
Please cite this article as: Maria, Javed Khattak, Ralf Ludwig, Khurshid Ayub, NANO-CAGES Phosphides or nitrides for better NLO properties? A detailed comparative study of alkali metal doped nano-cages, Materials Research Bulletinhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.materresbull.2017.03.065

The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
<AT>NANO-CAGESPhosphides or Nitrides for Better NLO Properties? A Detailed Comparative Study of Alkali Metal Doped Nano-cages
Mariaa, Javed Khattakb,c, Ralf Ludwigd,e, Khurshid Ayuba* Khurshid@ciit.net.pk
<AU>aDepartment of Chemistry, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Abbottabad, Pakistan, 22060 <AFF>bDepartment of Chemistry, University of Agriculture, Faisalabad, Pakistan, 38040 <AFF>cPunjab Bio-energy Institute, University of Agriculture, Faisalabad, Pakistan, 3804 <AFF>dLeibniz-Institut für Katalyse e. V. an der Universität Rostock, Albert-Einstein-Str. 29a, 18059 Rostock, Germany <AFF>eDepartment of Physical Chemistry, University of Rostock, Dr.-Lorenz-Weg 1, 18059 Rostock, Germany
<PA>*Corresponding authors.: Khurshid Ayub, Tel.: +92-992-383591; Fax: +92-992-383441.
<ABS-Head><ABS-HEAD>Graphical abstract <ABS-P> <ABS-P><xps:span class="xps_Image">fx1</xps:span>
<ABS-HEAD>Highlights► Alkali metal doped boron and aluminum phosphide nano-cages are evaluated for NLO properties ► The NLO response of phosphide nano-cages is compared with nitride nano-cages ► Phosphide nano-cages show better NLO properties than the corresponding nitride nano-cages. ► Conductivity of doped nano-cages is much higher than pristine nanocages ► MAl11P12 and MB11P12 show monotonic increase in hyperpolarizability with size of alkali metal
<ABS-HEAD>Abstract <ABS-P>Phosphide nano-cages of MX12P11 and MX11P12 (where X=B or Al, M=Li, Na, K) type are investigated theoretically for geometric, electronic and nonlinear optical (NLO) properties. Alkali metal is doped by replacing (a) aluminum or boron atom and (b) phosphorus atom. Alkali metal doping can remarkably alter the electronic and NLO properties of the nano-cages, regardless of doping site. HOMO-LUMO gap is decreased whereas first hyperpolarizability is enhanced significantly in doped AlP and BP nano-cages. PDOS (partial density of states) analysis suggests that diffuse excess electrons from alkali metal play important role in boosting NLO properties of phosphide nano-cages.TD-DFT calculations are performed to study the effect of alkali metal doping on absorption spectra. Red shift is observed in the UV-vis spectra of all considered nano-cages. Comparison of phosphide nano-cages with nitride nano-cages indicated that doping nitride nano-cages with alkali metal leads to greater hyperpolarizability and NLO response than doping phosphide nano-cages. <KWD>Keywords: Boron phosphide nano-cages; Aluminum phosphide nano-cages; Alkali metal doping; Enhanced (hyper)polarizability; Non Linear Optical properties Introduction
The field of nanoscience and nanotechnology has grown rapdily since the large scale synthesis of C60 fullerene [1]. Nano materials such as nano-cages, nanoclusters and nanotubes (due to the high surface/volume ratio) find applications in optical devices, catalysts [2], sensors [3], adsorption [4,5], medical [6,7] and electronic devices [8–10]. Numerous efforts have been made to explore non-carbon analogues of fullerene due to their unique structure and electronic properties. Recently, inorganic (XY)n fullerene of group III-V have gained considerable interest due to their applications in electronic devices [11] and light emitting diodes (LED’s) [12]. X12Y12, X16Y16, X24Y24,and X28Y28 nano-cages are important inorganic (XY)n fullerenes (where X= group III atom and Y= group V atom) [13]. Theoretical studies on these fullerene like nano-cages showed that (XY)12 are magic clusters with highest thermodynamic stability [14,15]. Inorganic nano-cages such as Al12N12, B12N12, Al12P12, and B12P12 are quite appealing since they have remarkable chemical and physical properties [16]. These nano-cages are large band gap semiconductors [13]. Reports on B12N12 have shown that, due to its unique structural properties, B12N12 has applications in adsorption [17] and opto-electrical devices [18]. Al12P12 nanocluster is also important for its large band gap properties which make it interesting candidate for theoretical studies [19]. B12P12 is a refractory semiconducting material. It has strong covalent binding properties for a variety of surfaces therefore, it is ideal for working in harsh conditions. Several reports are found in the literature on adsorption and catalytic applications of Al12P12 nano-cages [5,20–22] and B12P12 nano-cage [23]. Recently, designing advanced materials with high performance nonlinear optical (NLO) properties have attracted both industry and academia. NLO materials have potential applications in electronic and optoelectronic fields such as optical data storage, optical limiting, optical communication and biomedical science [24–35]. Different strategies have been proposed to realize high performance NLO materials. Presence of electron donor and electron acceptor on either end of conjugated systems (push-pull mechanism) is an effective strategy to design highly efficient organic nonlinear optical materials [31,36]. Incorporation of transition metal (electron rich) into organic framework can accelerate metalligand charge transfer transitions. The strategy of adjusting the number and position of metals can remarkably increase the NLO response of metal-ligand compounds [32,35]. Very recently, Li et al., [37–40] introduced an interesting approach where diffuse excess electrons are incorporated in a system for improving NLO response. Diffuse excess electrons can considerably increase hyperpolarizability of system which is responsible for enhancement of NLO properties (up to 1.52 x 104 au) [41][42]. In this regard, several studies have been performed on both organic and inorganic molecules. Lithium doping on B10H14 basket leads to significant increase in hyperpolarizability (2.31 x 104 au) due to diffuse excess electrons of Li atom [43]. πconjugated systems (pyrrole, benzene, thiophene) interacting with alkali atoms were studied, and it was shown that s valence electrons of alkali metal atoms are pulled out under the influence of π electron cloud of aromatic ring. These diffuse excess electrons then lead to larger fist hyperpolarizability [44]. Alkali metal atom doped calix[4]pyrrole has shown remarkably high hyperpolarizability value (7.3 x 103 au). S valence electrons of alkali metal were pulled out by lone pair of N atom present in the pyrrole ring [39]. Alkali doped AlN nano-cages were studied by Huang et al., where NLO response of nano-cage increased several times (8.89 x 105 au) [45]. In our earlier work, we investigated the NLO properties of alkali metal doped BN nano-cages (substitutional doping), and the results showed remarkable increase in first hyperpolarizability value of BN nano-cage [46].
We are interested in the comparative study of NLO response of alkali metal doped aluminum phosphide and boron phosphide nano-cages. Alkali metal can be doped on different positions such as on top of nano-cage (exohedral), encapsulation in nano-cage (endohedral), and substitution with any atom of nano-cage (substitutional). We have studied the substitution of alkali on two different positions, site of Al/B atom (where alkali atom M (M= Li, Na, K) replaces Al or B atom) or site of P atom (where alkali M (M= Li, Na, K) replaces p atom). Comprehensively, we will be investigating the effect of doping alkali metal on band gap, hyperpolarizability, and molecular absorption spectra. Further, comparison of hyperpolarizability of AlP nano-cage and BP nano-cage with nitride nano-cages will also be examined.

sections.heading: Methodology
sections.text:
All calculations were performed with Gaussian 09 suit of programs [47]. Geometries were optimized at B3LYP/6-31++G(d, p) level of theory without any symmetry constrains. Spin polarized DFT study is performed where singlet, triplet and quintet states of the doped nanocages are considered, in order to locate the lowest energy structure. Frequency calculations have been performed at the same level to confirm the nature of minima. No imaginary frequency is found for these structures which confirm them as true minima. Stability of pure and doped systems was evaluated by binding energies:
(Adsorption)
For M@X12P11 Ebind = EXPM – (EX12P11 + EM) For M@X11P12 Ebind = EXPM – (EX11P12 + EM) Where, EXPM is the zero point corrected energy of alkali doped aluminum phosphide and boron phosphide nano-cages and EM is the zero point corrected energy of alkali metal. Natural bond orbital (NBO) calculations were also performed at B3LYP/6-31++G(d, p) for charge analysis. Polarizability and first hyperpolarizability were calculated through long range correlated method at CAM-B3LYP/6-311+g(d) level of theory. CAM-B3LYP/6-311+g(d) is the best reported level of theory for the calculation of first hyperpolarizability [46,48,49]. First hyperpolarizability and mean polarizability are denoted as
Polarizability α = 1/3(αxx, αyy, αzz) First hyperpolarizability
β0 = [(βxxx + βxyy + βzzz) 2 + (βyyy + βyzz + βyxx) 2 + (βzzz + βzxx + βzyy) 2]1/2
Moreover, TD-DFT (time dependent DFT) calculations were executed on CAM-B3LYP/6311+g(d) level of theory for absorption spectra and calculation of crucial excited states of all the structures. Partial density of states (PDOS) were generated through multiwfn software [50]. .
Results and Discussion

sections.heading: Geometric parameters:
sections.text:
All the optimized structures of aluminum phosphide and boron phosphide nano-cages are presented in Figure 1. The geometries of optimized clusters are in agreement with previous reports [16]. Bond lengths in pure Al12P12 and B12P12 nano-cages are about 2.33 Å and 1.94 Å, respectively. Both nano-cages consist of eight hexagonal and six tetragonal rings. Here, both the nano-cages were doped with alkali metal at two different positions: (1) by replacing phosphorous atom in nano-cage with alkali metal (MAl12P11 and MB12P11), and (2) by replacing aluminum or boron atom in nano-cage (MAl11P12 and MB11P12) (figure 2 and 3). It is depicted from table 1, that B/Al-M (where alkali metal M is bonded to B or Al atom) or P-M (where alkali metal M is bonded to P atom) bond lengths increase with increase in atomic number of alkali metal atom. For MAl12P11, bond length increases from 2.33 Å in pure AlP nano-cage to 2.9 Å for LiAl12P11, which further increases to 3.4 Å for NaAl12P11. KAl12P11 has higher bond length of 3.6 Å in
series. Similarly, KAl11P12 has highest bond length of 3.1 Å in MAl11P12 series whereas LiAl11P12 and NaAl11P12 bond length are 2.6 Å and 2.9 Å, respectively. Similarly, bond lengths increase for heavier alkali atom in case of B12P12 nano-cages. For MB12P11, KB12P11 has the highest bond length of 2.9 Å. LiB12P11 and NaB12P11 have bond length of 2.4 Å and 2.7 Å, respectively. LiB11P12 has bond length of 2.6 Å in MB11P12 series. Bond lengths further increase to 2.9 Å and 3.1 Å for NaB11P12 and KB11P12, respectively. It is clear from the table that B/Al-M or P-M bond elongation in MAl12P11 is larger than MB12P11, upon alkali atom doping. NBO analysis:
NBO analysis was performed to find out the charge transfer in alkali metal doped phosphide nano-cages. It is clear from the results (table 1) that charge is being transferred from alkali atom to nano-cages. All considered doped nano-cages have negative charge while alkali metals have positive charge. An overall increase in charge on alkali metal is observed with increase in alkali atomic number in both nano-cages that can be attributed to ease of ionization of alkali atom down the group. It is expected that s valence electrons from alkali are transferred to nano-cage. Charge on alkali metal is in range of 0.55 to 0.94 for AlP nano-cages. KAl12P11 has the highest charge (0.94) in MAl12P11 series and KAl11P12 has highest charge (0.92) in MAl11P12 series. For BP nano-cages the range of NBO charge is 0.67 to 0.89. KB12P11 and KB11P12 have highest charges (0.89 and 0.83, respectively) than Li and Na doped BP nano-cages.

sections.heading: Dipole moment
sections.text:
Dipole moments of all considered clusters are shown in table 1. Pure nano-cages have negligible dipole moments (~ 0 Debye). An increasing trend of dipole moment is observed with increase in atomic number of alkali atom which can be ascribed to higher charge separation. Charge separation increases for heavier atom which results in larger dipole moment of heavier alkali metal doped structures. Al12P12
For MAl12P11 and MAl11P12 series, KAl12P11 and KAl11P12 have highest dipole moments of about 13.5 and 9.14 Debye, respectively. NaAl12P11 and NaAl11P12 have dipole moments of 7.83 Debye and 5.66 Debye, respectively. The lowest values of dipole moments are observed by LiAl12P11 (5.81) and LiAl11P12 (4.42). B12P12
For boron phosphide nano-cages, KB12P11 and KB11P12 have highest dipole moment of 10.4 Debye and 10.9 Debye, respectively which indicates highly polar nature of these nano-cages. Li doped BP nano-cages (LiB12P11 and LiB11P12) have lowest dipole moments (in their respective series) of 3.85 and 4.47 Debye. NaB12P11 and NaB11P12 have values of 8.39 and 7.02, respectively. Doped AlP nano-cages show higher dipole moments than doped BP nano-cages. The reason is longer bond lengths and higher charge separation in the AlP nano-cages.

sections.heading: Binding Energy:
sections.text:
Al12P12
Binding energies are calculated for all doped nano-cages. For MAl12P11 series, KAl12P11 have the highest binding energy of -45 kcal mol-1 which indicates its highly stable nature when compared with LiAl12P11 (-25 kcal mol -1) and NaAl12P11 (-13 kcal mol -1). The situation is somewhat different for MAl11P12. LiAl11P12 has shown highest stability (in MAl11P12 series) with binding energy value of -78 kcal mol-1. NaAl11P12 and KAl11P12 have binding energies of -64 kcal mol -1 and -65 kcal mol-1, respectively. B12P12
For B12P12 nano-cages, KB12P11 and NaB12P11 have almost equal stability in MB12P11 series (-86 kcal mol-1 and -85 kcal mol-1, respectively), while LiB12P11 is least stable having binding energy of -54 kcal mol-1. For MB11P12 series, LiB11P12 has highest binding energy of -75 kcal mol -1. NaB11P12 and KB11P12 have binding energies of of -62 kcal mol -1 and -65 kcal mol-1, respectively.
It is seen that Al-site and B-site series in both nano-cages have higher stability than P-site series. This can be credited to the electronegative atoms (P) attached to alkali in Al/B-site series as there were strong binding interactions between alkali and neighboring phosphorus atoms. Furthermore, it is depicted from table that BP doped nano-cages are relatively more stable than doped AlP nano-cages. The results in Table 1 illustrate that all properties decrease or increase monotonically with the atomic number of doped alkali metal atom. With the monotonic trends of properties, the irregular behavior of adsorption energies is very perplexing. We believe that the trend can be explained to some extent by considering covalent and ionic bonding between metal atom and nano-cage. For lithium doped nano-cages, short between metal and nano-cages combined with small charge separation is indicative of covalent bonding. On the other hand, bonding of sodium and potassium with nano-cages may be ionic in character where the strength of the bond depends on the quantities of charges present. The ionic nature of the bond is prevailing more for potassium doped nano-cages which illustrates why the binding energies of potassium with nano-cages are higher than those of sodium in all cases. The binding energies of lithium with nano-cages may be greater or smaller than those of sodium depending on the nature and strength of covalent bond in the former.

sections.heading: Electronic properties
sections.text:
Phosphide nano-cages such as AlP and BP are large band gap (3.37 eV and 3.66 eV, respectively) semiconductors. Potential applications of these nano-cages have been camouflaged behind this relatively large band gap. Effect of alkali metal doping on band gap of these nanocages is studied here for MX12P11 and MX11P12 (X=B or Al, M=Li, Na, K). It is obvious from the results that HOMO-LUMO gap is significantly lowered for alkali doped nano-cages (table 3). Al12P12
For MAl12P11, band gap is lowered to about 1.68 eV for NaAl12P11. LiAl12P11 and KAl12P11 have H-L gaps of 1.79 eV and 2.20 eV, respectively. On the other hand, in case of MAl11P12 series, KAl11P12 is found to have lowest H-L gap of 2.23 eV. There is not significant difference between the ∆E values of both series; however, the H-L gaps for MAl12P11 series are lower than MAl11P12 series. NaAl11P12 has H-L gap of 2.32 eV which is somewhat lowered to 2.31 eV for LiAl11P12. For boron phosphide nano-cages, NaB12P11 has highest band gap of 1.8 eV in MB12P11 series which is lowered down to 1.24 eV for LiB12P11. KB12P11 has lowest value (1.12 eV) in the series. In contrary, increasing trend of ∆E for heavier alkali is seen in MB11P12 series, where LiB11P12 has the lowest value of 2.6 eV. NaB11P12 and KB11P12 have values of 2.63 eV and 2.71 eV, respectively. Orbitals of all doped nano-cages are shown in figure 4 and 5. Alkali metal doping causes remarkable decrease in band gap of all doped systems. For better understanding, TDOS (total density of states) were plotted for considered doped and undoped systems. It is depicted that a new energy level in doped nano-cages is introduced between the original HOMO and LUMO as new HOMO. Hence the old HOMO becomes HOMO-1 which results in lowering of band gap. For Al12P12 nano-cage, original HOMO is present at -6.75 eV and LUMO is present at -3.37 eV with a Fermi level of -5.06 eV. Whereas new fermi levels are
present at -3.48 eV, -3.33 eV, -3.51 eV, -4.05 eV, -3.93 eV and -3.71 eV for LiAl12P11, NaAl12P11, KAl12P11, LiAl11P12, NaAl11P12 and KAl11P12, respectively. B12P12
Original HOMO and LUMO in B12P12 nano-cages were present at -6.92 and -3.25, respectively with a Fermi level at -5.08 eV. New Fermi levels for LiB12P11, NaB12P11, KB12P11, LiB11P12, NaB11P12 and KB11P12 appeared at –3.21 eV, -3.40 eV, -2.96 eV, -4.33 eV, -4.21 eV and -4.08 eV, respectively. It is expected that these new HOMO levels are hosted from alkali metal (figure 5). To confirm this notion, we have plotted partial densities of states (PDOS). In some cases (such as NaAl12P11), PDOS confirmed the involvement of valence electrons of alkali metal in the formation of new HOMO. It is clearly seen that HOMO is located on alkali metal and nano-cage which approves the fact that diffuse excess electrons from alkali metal are contributing in formation of new energy levels in NaAl12P11. For other alkali metal doped nano-cages of AlP and BP, involvement of diffuse excess electrons in formation of new HOMO levels is not clear. PDOS of structures having lowest band gaps in each series are shown in figure 6.

sections.heading: Molecular absorption:
sections.text:
Variation in band gap by doping alkali in nano-cages depicted some shift in optical absorption of these considered systems. TD-DFT studies were performed to calculate excited transition states and excitation wavelengths (λmax) for both aluminum and boron phosphide nano-cages (both pure and doped). Here, λmax corresponds to the excitation wavelength which has the largest oscillator strength value. All the wavelengths (390 nm - 600 nm) of doped nano-cages were observed in visible region (380 nm-760nm) except KB12P11 (969 nm), that shows absorption in near IR region (table 2). Al12P12:
Pure Al12P12 has λmax at 350 nm which relates to transitions from H-3 → L. Red shift in original wavelength was seen for all doped AlP nano-cages. For MAl12P11 series, LiAl12P11 has least red shift and the λmax appears at 424 nm. Molecular orbital transitions correspond to HOMO → LUMO+5 and HOMO → LUMO+8 for LiAl12P11. NaAl12P11 has λmax value of 476 nm and corresponds to transitions from HOMO → LUMO+3. KAl12P11 has the maximum red shift in the series with λmax (488 nm) and transitions are described as HOMO → LUMO+2. In MAl11P12 series, LiAl11P12 has relatively shorter λmax of 390 nm compared to both NaAl11P12 and KAl11P12. Molecular orbital transitions were attributed to HOMO-2 → LUMO and HOMO-5 → LUMO. λmax further increased to 410 nm for KAl11P12 with transitions from HOMO-2 → LUMO and HOMO-5 → LUMO. NaAl11P12 has λmax at the longest wavelength (497 nm, HOMO → LUMO+2). Electronic spectra are shown in figure 7.
Table 2 Electronic properties of AlP vs BP nano-cages
B12P12:
Similarly, TD-DFT studies were performed for doped BP nano-cage, and compared with pure B12P12. B12P12 has λmax of 396 nm which corresponds to transitions from HOMO → LUMO. In MB12P11 series, red shifts to longer wavelengths were observed for all doped nano-cages (similar to AlP series). NaB12P11 has shortest λmax of 347 nm and molecular transitions were credited to HOMO-3 → LUMO and HOMO-6 → LUMO. LiB12P11 has next higher λmax in the series (402 nm), and transitions for this wavelength are attributed to HOMO → LUMO+4. λmax increases further to 557 nm for KB12P11 with molecular orbital transitions from HOMO → LUMO+1 and HOMO → LUMO+3. The higher wavelength may be credited to the lowest band gap of KB12P11.
For MB11P12 series, λmax are found at 358 nm, 446 nm and 366 nm for LiB11P12, NaB11P12 and KB11P12, respectively. NaB11P12 was found to have longest λmax in the series with molecular orbital transitions from HOMO → LUMO+3 and HOMO → LUMO+2. λmax for LiB11P12 (358 nm) and KB11P12 (366 nm) are very comparable. Molecular transitions were ascribed to HOMO4 → LUMO and HOMO-6 → LUMO for LiB11P12 and HOMO → LUMO+2 and HOMO → LUMO+3.

sections.heading: NLO Properties
sections.text: 2S Valence electrons from alkali metal are ejected out as diffuse excess electrons and interaction between the core and valence electrons becomes very weak (vide supra). These diffuse excess electrons are easy to excite. Finally, crucial excitation energy of system becomes very low which alters the electronic properties of system. Hyperpolarizability is strongly dependent on energy of crucial excitation therefore, it is expected that hyperpolarizability of the considered systems will be significantly higher than bare nano-cages. To investigate the role of alkali metal doping on NLO properties of alkali doped nano-cages, polarizability (α) and first hyperpolarizability (β0) of phosphide nano-cages (Al12P12, B12P12) were calculated (table 3). Al12P12: For Al12P12 nano-cages, polarizability (α) of pure AlP nano-cage is 583 au, which increases gradually with the increase in the size of the alkali metal atom. In MAl12P11 series, α for LiAl12P11 is 627 au, which further increases to 644 au for NaAl12P11 and then to 649 au for KAl12P11. First hyperpolarizability of AlP nano-cages is also enhanced remarkably. LiAl12P11 and KAl12P11 are found to have comparable hyperpolarizability values of β0 of 2.8×10 3 au and 2.7×103, respectively while NaAl12P11 showed largest value of 6.3×10 3 au. Similarly, polarizability and first hyperpolarizability are also increased for MAl11P12 series. α increases to 601 au and 609 au for LiAl11P12 and NaAl11P12, respectively. KAl11P12 has largest α value of 617 au in the series. First hyperpolarizability has also shown increasing trend with increasing size of alkali metal atom. LiAl11P12 has β0 of 7.2×10 2 au which is lowest in series and it increases to 1.2×103 au for NaAl11P12. KAl11P12 showed highest β0 value of 1.4×10 3 au in the series.

sections.heading: B12P12 nano-cages:
sections.text:
B12P12 nano-cages are also investigated for polarizability and hyperpolarizability. The results showed significant increase in first hyperpolarizability of doped BP nano-cages. Polarizability (α) shows an increasing trend for heavier alkali metals. Pure BP has α value of 396 au which increases up to 411au for LiB12P11. Polarizability value for NaB12P11 and KB12P11 are 421 au and 448 au, respectively. β0 value for KB12P11 (8.0×10 2 au) is the lowest in the series. LiB12P11 has next higher value of 1.7×103 au and NaB12P11 has highest β0 value of 5.3×10 3 au. In MB11P12 series, a similar trend of polarizability is seen where LiB11P12 has α value of 413 au, which increased to 420 au and 426 au for NaB11P12 and KB11P12, respectively. LiB11P12 has lowest β0 of 7.5×102 au while first hyperpolarizability of NaB11P12 and KB11P12 was calculated to be almost same (1.4×103 au). It can be realized from the results in Table 3 that first hyperpolarizability values of AlP nanocages were greater than β0 values of BP nano-cages. Hence alkali doped AlP nano-cages are superior to BP nano-cages for better NLO response. Numerous factors play significant role in deciding the hyperpolarizability of a system, for instance, ionization potential and interaction distance. If a system has diffuse excess electrons then monotonic increase in hyperpolarizability is expected with increase in atomic number (size) of alkali metal. Due to increase in atomic number of alkali metal, ionization potential increases which results in easy ejection of valence
electrons. Several reports are present in literature on this behavior [40,51]. In our results MAl11P12 and MB11P12 shows this type of behavior. The other factor is interaction distance between alkali metal and nano-cage. If the distance is shorter between alkali metal and nano-cage, then hyperpolarizabilities will be high Hence, a monotonic decrease in hyperpolarizability is predictable with increase in atomic number of alkali atom. This trend is also reported for many compounds [52]. Absence of monotonic behavior in case of MAl12P11 series and MB12P11 series depicts that neither the ionization potential nor interaction distance is solely playing role in deciding hyperpolarizability of the nano-cages. Therefore, it is expected that combination of both factors (ionization potential and interaction distance) play their role in deciding hyperpolarizability of the nano-cages. The higher hyperpolarizability of NaAl12P11 over KAl12P11 is probably due to smaller interaction distance of the former. LiB12P11 has higher hyperpolarizability over KB12P11 which may be due to smaller distance in LiB12P11. Comparison: We have previously reported hyperpolarizabilities of alkali metal doped AlN and BN nano-cages [46] [53]. Here, we compare hyperpolarizabilities of phosphide nano-cages with nitride nanocages. Moreover, hyperpolarizabilities of substitutional doped nano-cages are also compared with endohedral and exohedral complexes. Hyperpolarizability values are shown in Table 3 and it is clearly seen that the hyperpolarizabilities of Al-site or B-site doped phosphide nano-cages are not significantly different from the hyperpolarizabilities of Al-site or B-site doped nitride nano-cages. However, hyperpolarizabilities of N-site doped nitride nano-cages are much larger than the hyperpolarizabilities of P-site doped phosphide nano-cages. It is also obvious that doped BN nano-cages have largest hyperpolarizability values whereas doped BP nano-cages have lowest hyperpolarizability values. Furthermore, from figure 8 it is perceived that N-site or P-site doped nano-cages have higher hyperpolarizability values than Al-site or B-site doped nanocages. Also, there is not much difference in hyperpolarizability values of Al-site or B-site doped nano-cages and a huge difference is seen among hyperpolarizability of N-site or P-site doped nano-cages. Recently, nonlinear optical properties of alkali metal encapsulated nitride and phosphide nanocages are studied. The hyperpolarizabilities of endohedral complexes are increased several times by alkali metal doping with maximum of 5.7 x 105 au for potassium encapsulated BP nano-cage. In contradiction to our results on substitutional doping, hyperpolarizabilities of phosphide nanocages are higher than nitrides nano-cages. The hyperpolarizabilities of substitutional doped nitrides nano-cages (our case) are an order of magnitude higher than the hyperpolarizabilities of the corresponding endohedral nitride nano-cages[54]. The hyperpolarizabilities of exohedral alkali metal doped AlN nano-cages yet remain the highest so far (8.89 x105 au), among all studied nano-cages for alkali metal doping [45]. Other nano-cages like, exohedral and endohedral alkali metal doped MgO and BeO were also investigated for their NLO properties. Hyperpolarizability values for these nano-cages are increased considerably for exohedral doping (2.7 x 104 au) whereas encapsulation leads to relatively smaller hyperpolarizability values (2.8 x 103 au) [55].

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
In the current studies, substitutional doping of phosphide nano-cages (AlP, BP) is studied theoretically for improving electronic and nonlinear optical properties. Doping alkali metal in the nano-cages remarkably enhances the opto-electric properties of these systems. NBO analysis showed charge transfer from alkali metal to nano-cage in all
considered structures. Increase in bond lengths of doped BP nano-cages is higher than the increase in bond lengths of AlP nano-cages. AlP nano-cages have binding energies in range of -39 kcal mol-1 to -78 kcal mol-1. Doped AlP nano-cages show have higher binding energies than doped BP nano-cages. Alkali metal doping can efficiently lower down the HOMO-LUMO gaps in all doped nano-cages. Band gaps of doped AlP nanocages were in a range of 1.67 eV - 2.29 eV, much lower than band gap of pure Al12P12 nano-cage (3.38 eV). Band gap for doped BP nano-cages were in a range of 1.25eV -2.65 eV, compared to 3.67 eV for pure B12P12 nano-cage. TD-DFT calculations revealed red shift in absorption spectra for all doped nano-cages. For doped AlP nano-cages, λmax lie in a range of 479 nm – 555 nm (visible region). Whereas, λmax for all doped BP nano-cages reside in visible range (418 nm – 688 nm) except KB12P11, which has λmax at 969 nm (near IR region). Furthermore, doping alkali into nano-cage greatly enhances the polarizability and first hyperpolarizability. First hyperpolarizabilities of doped AlP nano-cages were as high as 6.4×103 au for NaAl12P11. For BP nano-cages highest first hyperpolarizability is calculated for NaB12P11 (2.2×10 3 au). Results suggested that first hyperpolarizabilities of doped AlP nano-cages are much higher than for doped BP nano-cages. Comparison of phosphide nano-cages with nitride nano-cages (Al12N12 and B12N12) revealed that nitride nano-cages have larger first hyperpolarizability values than phosphide nano-cages. It is concluded that doping alkali in nano-cage whether phosphide or nitride, can significantly enhances NLO properties of the nano-cage. The alkali doped phosphide nano-cages can be used as promising materials in opto-electronic devices. <ACK>Acknowledgements Author acknowledge financial support from Higher Education Commission (HEC), through Grant number 1899, 2469, 2981. The authors also acknowledge support from COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Abbottabad. <REF>References <BIBL> [1] H.W. Kroto, J.R. Heath, S.C. O’Brien, R.F. Curl, R.E.
